ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I got to watch a lot of movies I both had wanted to or didn't know about and got to see more perspectives of how filmmakers perceived different wars.
None. Literally no new knowledge, skills, or insights. A class that added nothing.
I learned how to analyze war films and pick out common themes. I learned about warrior culture and how that is embodied throughout different films from different time periods.
I developed a greater understanding of the American military and the history of American war films. The best part was watching the movies themselves.
Watching and analyzing war films, and discussing the central themes in war films and warrior culture.
Knowledge of war films and warrior culture. Really cool dive into some classic war movies and how the influence/were influenced by a warrior culture in society and the military
I learned how to watch a film more precisely and identify broad trends across films in a genre. I also learned a lot about the relationship between the military and the public in the US.
Improved argumentative writing skills, learned how to do film analysis
Learned about trends in the film industry correlating with periods of war in US history. Especially the intentions of the directors and the effect of popular opinion at home.

I am really happy with the range of movies we covered and feel I accomplished my objectives going into the class: "I applied to ** to be a career **. Many service members join with military films in mind; I want to better understand cultural/ideological underpinnings of these motives & image of self influencing me & colleagues. I want to be comfortable talking about these films to help with the social component of leadership & have a stronger common frame of reference. Honestly, I will have a blast nerding out on military films with an instructor with extensive USCG experience & interested classmates" (my application statement). I now understand a lot more references to military films than I did before, and now feel I can actually have a solid conversation about military movies. I also appreciated readings on deeper themes, such as Vietnam-era social context for the film making industry, women, and the commentaries about 'why men like war' or the "seductive" nature of violence in military films.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think the structure of the seminar could be tweaked. Definitely keep the breakout discussions as those were the part of class I enjoyed and could speak freely and candidly about my thoughts on the film. If the class had followed the breakout room instructions (where there is one speaker to present to the class) I think it would have gone better. Unfortunately,that broke down and it ended up being every single person had to say something to show participation when the questions they were assigned to answer clearly didn't have enough substance to necessitate 4 people talking for 3-5 mins each. I'm not sure the mini presentations by each person in the class gave me anything. The midterm paper having three shorter essays was definitely better than the final paper which I really struggled with as it didn't have a clear question to answer like the midterm did (I'm sure this was done to give us more room to choose a topic we want, but when you don't have any ideas it's hard).

Ive been eagerly awaiting my opportunity to write an unfiltered review. Firstly, I would like to say I found the class material fascinating. At times, the readings came across as overly paranoid, trying to extricate seemingly insidious undertones when none exist, but on the whole, the films and readings provide an interesting perspective on a ubiquitous element of our culture. I also liked my classmates. They were cool people with whom I wouldnt mind taking future classes at Yale.

Unfortunately, these pros dont outweigh the problems. Yale should never offer this class again. 

Why, you may ask? John Garofolo.

He establishes himself as someone who intimately understands the writing process. He frequently cites his experience as a writing instructor for the Coast Guard or as a published author. But I found his own writings to be flawed. His instructions were riddled with grammatical errors (including improper subject-verb agreement and capitalization) and his writing style was akin to something I would have written in an on-demand essay in high school. That is to say, his own simplistic writings would not receive a high grade in his own class.

To be blunt, Garofolo is not a good writer. He insists on formulaic constructions of a thesis statement, for which sophisticated writers and thinkers do not have to be tethered. But further, he sees accurate thesis statements as not truly thesis statements for whatever strange reasons he may have. He pontificates at length in class on supporting arguments and the importance of having an arguable claim. These aphorisms akin to the wrappers in a fortune cookie dont attempt to constructively improve writing. It only boosts his ego in finding rhetorical deficiencies in Yale students. He also cares nothing for writing style. No discussion is made about the benefits of stylistic flare beyond an opening hook which is as banal as it is uncreative. Is there any wonder that his essay arguing that the Coast Guard should be moved to the Department of Defense was never accepted for publication?

Garofolos lack of writing ability raises an interesting question: how can he be called upon to grade his students if he himself is a substandard writer?

Easy! He nitpicks papers based on his own personal opinion on whether he agrees with an argument, and harps on the alleged non-existence of a thesis statement. Quite frankly, he only comprehends the existence of an argument if it was spoon-fed to him in his own writing style. He doesnt care about the points a student justifies. He says he does not expect us to be film critics. Fine! But provide substantive ways for us to improve with actionable goals (dare I say, provide an arguable claim to your own argumentation?).  But instead, he mysteriously held his students to near-insurmountable standards. Of course, he never described how he arrived at his grade determinationshis comments, whenever provided, were sparse and often incorrect to boot! For example, a noun and verb exist as a common homophone in the English language. He made a point of editing my use of the verb, replacing it with the noun! These types of edits made me seriously question how rigorously he graded papers. Beyond this, his comments on papers were frequently condescending, degrading, and wholly detached from the reality of good writing. Im sorry, but he made someone in my smaller group almost cry when discussing their grade because he was so insulting in the comments (which, mind you, lacked any substance). 

I had a terrible experience in this class. I took this to learn more about the world but instead learned of one mans desire to feel superior to his students.

Strengths: carefully picked out movies that all brought good discussion to class, breakout rooms for discussions 
Weaknesses: sometimes presenting what we discussed in our groups to the class wasn't as engaging as the class discussions on a certain idea

I thought the film list was well developed and this was a strength of the course. I also generally liked the essay assignments and thought our class did a good job building community over Zoom. I also liked the breakout discussions as it allowed us to meet each other. In terms of weaknesses, I thought the essay grading was fairly harsh and confusing and I struggled to really see myself improve across the semester. I felt Prof G had a very specific argument/perspective he was looking for in each essay, and if we strayed from this, we would not do well.

Strengths - the level of participation was very high despite us all being on zoom, which was nice. 
Weaknesses - Since we can only watch/discuss a limited number of films in class, students felt disappointed in a few of the movie selections. However, the overall movie selections and supplemental readings were awesome.

Strengths: Movies were great, format was great, readings were the first time in a seminar Ive taken that i did not feel like they were arbitrarily given just to make students have something to read

Weaknesses: assignment instructions were sometimes unclear

Strengths - the professor knows a lot about the topic, essays really help guide your thinking about the material. 
Weaknesses - too big to be a proper seminar class, breakout rooms could have been shuffled around better.

Strengths - good discussion prompts, fun breakout rooms, excellent films for screening 

Weaknesses - occasionally slow to start the real discussion in class

The strength is the high engagement level among students.  The 3-4 people breakout room discussions involve everyone in a more intimate setting where you can get to know classmates' interpretations and explanations fairly freely as opposed to the full seminar setting where it is sometimes harder to engage with so many people. 
The weakness could be the hit or miss quality of conversation based on personal convictions on movies and limited weeks to evaluate films.

Great course, organization, selection of films, and engaging discussion and discussion format. One weakness: Professor Garofolo isn't too open to any other ideas or narratives other than the one he has formulated for the course. If students have other perspectives, it is better to deem them as interesting or creative rather than "right" or "wrong". So, it is good to think outside of the box, especially with such an interesting course that invites unconventional discussion.

I thought the class was well organized and executed, with interesting content and movies I would not have otherwise watched. For example, I love the movie In Harm's Way, and definitely would not have picked it up on my own had I not watched it for class. Granted, the rest of the class voted to cut this particular one, but the overarching point of my comment stands. The class already gave feedback about specific movie and reading choices to the Professor during our last class. One thing I would say is that for a student who plans ahead and does not procrastinate, this class can be a bit hard to plan for. Readings are often not posted until three of four days in advance, not the customary week, and readings are changed or added with less than three days notice, sometimes the day before. I felt bad bugging Professor Garofolo on weekends about readings, but I had full days on Monday and Tuesday (starting at 5:50AM) and my preference was to get work done for this class (which met Wednesday) on Friday or Saturday. The movies though were posted in advance for the entire term, and extras were posted as well to supplement our essays or just to watch for fun, which was great. Overall, I really enjoyed this class and appreciated the opportunity.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Breakout rooms were a big plus. Please try to keep something like that when classes go back in person.

This class shouldn't be offered again but if it were, students should be allowed to engage with the points others were making, rather than receiving "good" from the instructor without any additional insight offered.
The Zoom breakout rooms used for discussion were great!  It gave us time to meet new people , as well as discuss our ideas and the movie in a more intimate and easy way.
I really enjoyed the breakout discussions that we used over Zoom. I also liked the ability to watch films on our own time.

Success: breakout rooms were awesome

Improve: some small hiccups technologically
Prof. Garofolo could have benefitted from some Zoom education to prepare him for virtual education.
This virtual seminar worked. The breakout room feature was optimized.

Virtual seminar over the Zoom was the best that this course could've been done. Yet, Prof Garofolo made the course super engaging nevertheless! Prof Garofolo split us into discussion groups of 4 to talk, then had us come together at the end of the class to discuss.

Professor Garofolo's breakout rooms were brilliantfour people was perfect, and having the same room for several weeks was great. It allowed us to have extended discussions about themes or ideas and just pick up were we left off, and make friends in the class in a remote environment. We gave the professor more detailed feedback in the last class; overall, I'd say Professor Garofolo ran a great class over zoom in the pandemic environment!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend it if you enjoy watching war movies as I do, but would caution against taking it if you care about your GPA. Unbeknownst to me before I took the class, it's a hard class to get an A in which is bad as it's a college seminar and you expect a fun an interesting class that you will do well in if you put in the work. The grading is pretty harsh and is basically only based off your writing skill even though it's not a writing credit. I'd recommend C/D/F if you can and then you won't have to worry and can just enjoy watching and discussing war films. A bonus, is that there are more films made available to you via the course reserves than required to watch so you can watch even more than 1film/week and not have to pay to rent films.

I highly suggest this class if you like war films or movies in general. The readings were interesting and almost always pertained to the film being viewed that week, which enhanced the experience. The writing wasn't super demanding, but you still have to put forth a good effort. Professor G. was an English instructor at some point during his career and grades as such.
No no no no no no no no no no no
The content of this class is interesting.  I came in with no military background and have learned a great amount about warrior culture and the military through the films and discussion.

I would not recommend this course to another student. Although the movies were enjoyable, you can easily watch them on your own time. The grading and related feedback was too frustrating to make this class worth it.
Yes. If you are interested in the topic, or want to get pretty cool insight into some great war movies, I would definitely take the class.
I would recommend this class to anyone who is interested in exploring the dynamic between the military and the American public or learning how to watch films more closely.
I would. Its a fun class that will make you think much deeper about war films and American culture.

Would highly recommend to anyone regardless of major.   HOWEVER, this course skims over arriving at consensus on warrior culture and leaves the definition open to interpretation. The theme is touched upon with every movie, however this course should be thought of as a war films course, not a seminar examining warrior lifestyles and ethics.
Yes, if you are especially interesting about the military culture that seems to permeate the US.

I would absolutely recommend! Take a look at the syllabus for topics and movies. Professor Garofolo ran a great classthe breakout rooms were fun and we covered a solid amount of content. I enjoyed talking about the movies with friends also going into the military outside of class too, especially the Navy/USMC movies (there was even a SWO movie, which was cool), and am happy for the chance to watch and talk about them with engaged peers and a professor with USCG experience who knows how the military works and can give thoughtful insights. Professor Garofolo was generous with office hours as well!

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Film screenings on our own time.
Separate online screenings.
none

Class met in a live virtual seminar format with weekly reviews of films and spaced out writing assignments. Heavy use of breakout room discussions with instructor guidance through assigned discussion prompts.

extras.title:
CSBF 330 01
        War Films and Warrior Culture
